title: Diageo sells golf's Gleneagles hotel as it focuses on core business
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Jul 2, 2015, 06:38 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 22 mins Diageo sells golf's Gleneagles hotel as it focuses on core business By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 17 hours ago 1,874.00 +33.00 
Drinks giant Diageo (LSE: DGE.L - news ) sells hotel that was the venue for Europe's victory over the US at 2014 Ryder Cup 
Diageo has sold Gleneagles Hotel, scene of Europe’s triumph over the US in last year’s Ryder Cup, as the drinks company looks to focus on its core business having reaped the benefits of the golf tournament. 
Opened in 1924, the five-star hotel and golf course complex set in 850 acres in Perthshire, Scotland, has been owned by Diageo since 1984. In 2014 it hosted golf’s Ryder Cup tournament. 
The company also used the hotel to promote its scotch brands, regularly holding tournaments there, most notably the Johnnie Walker championship. 
Gleneagles' courses are on the "bucket lists" of many golfers after the Ryder Cup was held there 
FTSE 100-listed Diageo sold the property to a private investment group led by property and hospitality firm Ennismore , which develops and operates upmarket hotels, bars and restaurants in Europe and the US under The Hoxton brand. 
• In pictures: The 2014 Ryder Cup 
Gleneagles, which was bought by Ennismore for an undisclosed amount, had revenues of £43.5m in the year to June 30 2014, and made an operating profit of £2.6m with a return on invested capital of 4pc based on the property’s book value. 
Ivan Menezes, chief executive of Diageo, said: “We are proud to have been the owner of Gleneagles but the hotel is not a core business for us and therefore following the success of the Ryder Cup we feel this is an appropriate time to realise value through this transaction. 
“I am pleased that Diageo’s brands, especially our scotch brands, will continue to be an important feature at this iconic Scottish hotel. We wish Ennismore and all the staff at the hotel a successful future.”
